This is a guide to attractions and things to do near the venue of the

, from 6 to 10 August 2014.  People from around the world are expected to attend, and many will want to explore the city and beyond while they're here, either in the evenings after the conference events or for a few days before or after the conference. There is also likely to be a separate, semi-organised Wikimania Fringe event during and after the conference itself.

Wikimania is the annual international conference for Wikimedia and its many projects (from the original Wikipedia to the recently adopted Wikivoyage).  Hundreds of Wikimedians from across the world travel to attend each event.  The first Wikimania was held in 2005 in Frankfurt, Germany.  Since then, Wikimanias have been held every year, always on a different continent.  London 2014 will be the 10th annual Wikimania and the third in Europe.
The conference is taking place at the Barbican Centre. The word "barbican" means a fortified outpost or gateway.  In this case, however, it is an estate on the north-west edge of the

.  It partially stands on land that was once a Roman fort, which was later incorporated in the wall that surrounded London until the Georgian era.  Some of the remains of the wall can still be seen in the Barbican estate.

The area has been destroyed and rebuilt several times.  As part of London, it was hit by the Black Death; in 1348-50 the bodies of plague victims were dumped in a local plague pit, which has recently been found under nearby Charterhouse Square.  In the first week of September 1666 this area, and almost everything around it, burned down during the Great Fire of London.  On 25 August 1940, at 00:15, the first bomb to land on London during World War II hit on Fore St, on the southern edge of the Barbican.  During the subsequent Blitz, the area that would become the Barbican was bombed flat by German air raids.  In 1965, work began on rebuilding the area, with a firm conviction to provide residential buildings to repopulate the City.  It was officially opened in 1969 although the Barbican Centre was not itself opened until 1982.

The whole estate is now Grade II listed and a site of special architectural interest as an important example of British brutalist architecture.

, usually just called "the City" and sometimes "the Square Mile", the original ancient and mediaeval boundaries of the city which retains its traditional form of government quite distinct from that of

.

The City is the banking and trading hub that makes London the financial capital of the world.  As the name implies, the City is a city in its own right, with its own bylaws and local government.  It is run by the
which is headed by the Lord Mayor of London (not the same as Mayor of London). Being reliant on the financial sector, the area can be pretty dead on the weekend, and many shops and pubs do not open.
has information for anyone planning to attend. Wikivoyage has guides to
in general and to the specific district known as the
, where the conference will be. We also have several London itinerary articles:

The conference is taking place at the

.  The Barbican Estate is a brutalist estate reminiscent of 70s science fiction (try not to imagine you are being hunted down by the totalitarian forces of a post-apocalyptic future).  It is residential as well as a container for the Centre, the Museum of London and other facilities; home to about four thousand people.  The Centre itself is the largest one of its kind in Europe and includes an art gallery, a cinema, a concert hall, a library, two theatres and even a conservatory—filled with birds, fish and tropical plants—on the top floor.

Bus number 153 stops the closest to the Barbican Centre.  It runs between Moorgate and Finsbury Park.
Bus numbers 4, 56 and 100 also stop fairly close to the Centre.
For a map of the local bus stops and associated routes, see the
(PDF) on the Transport for London website.

The closest Docklands Light Railway station is at
, about 12 minutes walk from the Barbican Centre.

This is by far the best way to get round London and cheap! If you are arriving at one of the central railway stations the journey will be quite short, perhaps 30 minutes. See below for more details but
racks are all around the Barbican. Remember to cycle on the left!

Most of the places in this guide are within easy reach of the Wikimania venue.  They should all be within easy walking distance for most attendees.

Buses are available throughout the area.  The closest bus stops to the venue are along Beech Street which is served by route 153, from the near-by Finsbury Square, north to Finsbury Park (in
).  On the other side of the Barbican Centre is London Wall which is served by route 100, from St Georges Town Hall (near Shadwell tube station in London's
), past the Tower of London and the Barbican, then south and across the Thames to Elephant and Castle (in
.  There are two Night Bus routes that also pass close to the venue.  Route 243, along Beech Street, connects Redvers Road (near Wood Green tube station in
. Route 242, along London Wall, connects Homerton Hospital (near Homerton mainline station in
).  For further routes and times, refer to the
website or to the maps and signs at any bus stop.
are recommended for using the buses because the fares are lower and there is an automatic maximum limit equal to the cost of a one-day travel pass.

" but often called "Boris Bikes" after the Mayor of London, is also available at the ubiquitous blue docking stations. Credit or debit cards are necessary to hire the bikes on an ad hoc basis, a flat charge is made to access the scheme but all journeys of less than 30 minutes are free and any number of free journeys can be made a day, however the bike must be returned before the end of each 30 minute period to qualify, after the first 30 minutes
the longer you keep the bike. The closest docking station is on Silk Street.  More local stations can be found on the

website and each docking station features a map indicating the other stations in the neighbourhood (these maps are also useful for pedestrians needing to orientate themselves).

Cycle racks are also available outside the venue, for those of you using your own bicycle.

The Barbican Estate is part of The Pedway, a failed 1960s attempt to create "streets in the sky" throughout The City.  The larger plan was never completed due to changing ideas and cut budgets, but the Barbican has a few Highwalk elevated walkways.  Be warned: they can be a bit of a maze and sometimes people do get lost.

value: content=The great domed cathedral of St Paul's, designed by Sir Christopher Wren to replace the Gothic medieval cathedral destroyed in 1666 in the Great Fire of London, was built between 1675–1710. Of the most famous London sights, St Paul's is the one most conveniently located for the Barbican. It's a significant building in British history, having been the site of the funerals of several British military leaders (Nelson, Wellington, Churchill), and significantly held peace services marking the end of the two world wars. The cathedral is also famous for its

, as well as its stunning view over the city. The crypt is also open to the public, holding the tombs of Nelson, Wellington and Christopher Wren. It is possible to sidestep the admission charge by entering for one of the midday services, even if you don't take part; however you'd still need a ticket to get to the top.
directions=entrances on Bunhill Row and City Road

content=Initially used to bury bones to make space at St Paul's, it was designated as a burial ground during the Great Plague of 1665. Notable interments include Daniel Defoe, John Bunyan and William Blake.
price=£4 admission for Adults, £1 for photography

content=Founded in 1123, by jester-turned-monk Rahere, this Norman church is one of the oldest in London. It was damaged in the Dissolution but managed to escape both the Great Fire and the Blitz. This is a Grade I listed building. Tourists are welcome when services are not in progress and are charged an admission fee (which does not apply to those coming to pray or use the café).

content=A medieval church that was rebuilt in the late 18th Century, noted for its well preserved interior. The former churchyard was converted into a public space in 1880, called Postman's Park as it was frequented by workers from the nearby Post Office headquarters.
directions=part of the Barbican Estate, across the lake from the Arts Centre

content=Medieval Grade I listed church. This church played a key role in the English Revolution and was the parish church of some of the most decisive Puritans: Oliver Cromwell was married and this where John Milton was buried. It was the home of the Morning Exercises The tower remains from the original building; the rest was destroyed in the Blitz but rebuilt based on the original plans.
content=John Wesley, founder of the Methodist church, laid the foundation stone, preached here and is buried behind the chapel. The site also contains the Museum of Methodism.
content=Charts the history of the bank from 1694 to the present day. A highlight is the opportunity to handle a genuine bar of gold.
content=Charts the history of clockmaking and houses a priceless collection of old timepieces.
name=Guildhall Art Gallery and Roman Amphitheatre
price=£2.50 (F and after 3:30PM: free), child 0-16 free

content=The Guildhall Art Gallery houses the City Corporation's art collection, and also runs special exhibitions throughout the year. During construction of the modern gallery, workers discovered the ruins of London's Roman amphitheatre. The gallery was redesigned, and now the Amphitheatre is open to the public within the Guildhall Art Gallery itself and also free of charge.
address=London Wall (NB: this is a street!)
directions=tube: Barbican (walk S) or St Pauls (walk N)
price=Permanent and temporary exhibitions: free. Special exhibitions: £5, concession £3, child 0-15 free

content=Established in 1975, the Museum of London explores the various threads of London's archaeology, history and culture throughout its more than 2,000 year old existence. Free and, like the City, endlessly fascinating! (The Museum now also has an offshoot in
.) Cafe, gift shop and disabled access.
name=Museum of the Order of St John
address=St John’s Gate, St John’s Lane, EC1M 4DA
content=Museum in the former English headquarters of the Knights Hospitaller, covering the history of the order from crusading knights to modern first aid organisation.
File:Plaque to the first WWII bomb to fall on London.jpg
directions=top floor of the Barbican Centre
content=The second biggest greenhouse in London, containing over 2,000 species of tropical plants as well as birds and fish.
directions=set in the wall of Roman House
content=The first of tens of thousands of bombs to hit London in World War II fell here in 1940. (NB obscured by building work, as of 22 June)

content=After leaving its brutalist skyscraper on Old Broad St, the London Stock Exchange now resides on Paternoster Sq. Dating back to 1698, it is one of the world's oldest and largest stock markets.
image=London Wall bastion, Barber Surgeons' Hall Gardens, London EC2.jpg

content=Remains of the wall that surrounded the City of London for almost two thousand years. The parts around the Barbican are mostly Tudor due to maintenance (Roman remains can be seen in and around the Tower of London). Other local remains are the
image=Roman Wall, Noble Street, London EC1 - geograph.org.uk - 1087379.jpg
directions=between Holborn Circus and St Paul's Cathedral, tube: St Paul's then follow signs

content=This is the probably the most famous criminal court in the world, and has been London's principal criminal court for centuries. It hears cases remitted to it from all over England and Wales as well as the Greater London area. The present building dates largely from 1907 (a new block was added from 1970 for more modern facilities) and stands on the site of the infamous medieval Newgate Gaol. The Central Criminal Court is of course best known today for its association with John Mortimer's
character, novels and television series. Daily case listings are available at
. No bags, cameras, drink, food or mobile phones—no facilities for safekeeping. Children under 14 not admitted.
directions=starts at the Advance Ticket desk, Silk St entrance
content=90-minute tour of the beautifully ugly brutalist site.
content=An exhibition of digital art and creativity, including film, music and games, and the effect of technology on the arts. Runs until 14 September.
name=The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier
directions=Level three of the Barbican Centre
content=An exhibition devoted to the French couturier featuring over a hundred garments and costumes. Runs until 25 August.
content=A tour of the constantly changing street art around this part of the East End. Saturday times may vary.
address=4th Floor, Development House, 56-64 Leonard St, EC2A 4LT
content=Visit the local Wikimedia chapter's office. Most staff will be at Wikimania but the office space will be open on the weekdays.

Late night bus tours are a nice way to see the sights around the city in the evening after attending Wikimania.

value: address=Departing from Coach stop 3, Bulleid Way
content=Trendy independent shops on a pedestrianised street.

content=Smithfield Market is London's largest wholesale meat market and hence a great source of fresh meat from Britain and around the world. Additionally, there are many good restaurants in the vicinity.

content=The City's only modern shopping centre, which opened in October 2010. Includes around 60 shops and restaurants. It is situated right by St Paul's Cathedral and is in a small area of retailing, including Cheapside and the cobbled, old-fashioned Bow Lane.
content=Situated opposite the Bank of England, the Exchange houses a number of upmarket outlets.
directions=alley between Fore St and Moorgate
content=Halal American-style diner, serving burgers, steaks, and grilled meat.  Good for Muslims on a budget and hungry, early-morning clubbers.
content=Small vegetarian restaurant with integral deli.
content=Easygoing gastro-pub with good quality, reasonably priced lunch menu, and tapas in the evening.
content=Grade II listed four-floor restaurant in Smithfield Market.
content=Real ale, nice food and a relaxed atmosphere.
image=Wood Street Bar and Restaurant, Barbican, EC2 (4160060518).jpg

content=A large, traditional pub, rebuilt in 1815 but claiming a history on this site back to 1641.  In good weather, outdoor tables in the square can be pleasant.  London legend claims that Stalin and Lenin first met in this pub, in a back room (under the "Conspirators' Clock") in 1903.
content=Small Belgian bar serving Belgian beer and Belgian food.

content=Independent traditional pub quite close to the Barbican.  Beers are often served in pewter tankards for the extra traditional touch.  Six rooms are available as well for those who want to sleep where they drink (or just near the Barbican).  Great atmosphere but it can be a little more expensive than average, especially the food and lodging.

content=A converted Georgian coffee shop, which sells the Norfolk beer, St. Peters.  The building is from the 1700s, remodelled in 1810, and it was converted in the 1990s, making this both a new and an old pub.  The interior is a little small so, while well worth a visit, after 17:00 on weekdays it gets quickly flooded with City workers.

content=A recently re-opened gastropub modelled on a traditional countryside drinking establishment, with a hunting theme.  The tables are actually old whisky barrels and the decor features several stuffed animals and trophies.  Completing the pattern, the food is heavily game-based, with some seafood.

content=This claims to be one of London's oldest pubs, tracing it history to 1610, although it has been rebuilt since then.  The eponymous Doctor Butler was a purveyor of "medicinal ale" who was appointed court physician to James I.  Pubs selling his beer were allowed to display his portrait, hence the name of the establishment.
content=Local CAMRA Pub of the Year 2011.  This traditional pub is best known for its large and varied beer selection, often from local and micro-breweries, both cask and bottled.
content=Small pub that serves real ale and craft beer from both major and local breweries.
address=3 Bastion Highwalk (125 London Wall), EC2Y 5AP
directions=along one of the raised walkways, not at ground level

content=A massive club (think cathedral scale) that provides a more underground version of Ministry of Sound and hosts some of the biggest names in dance music, from Goldie to David Holmes to the Scratch Perverts. There are always big queues, so get down early if you can.
content=Speakeasy-style cocktail bar.  Regular live music fitting the prohibition era theme.
content=Cocktail lounge in a Georgian townhouse.  Also offers some accommodation with thirteen rooms available for hire.
